by Ben Nolan

Not even a session.

The actual session was...

What's the state of VR on the web, rendering techniques, and challenges

• Mozilla is [doing a lot of things]

• Depth in CSS will be a thing

• WebGL2 and web workers [will be great]

If correctness is everything, work at Pixar. Realtime requires shortcuts.

I took this photo
because Marcus likes X-Wings

SceneVR!

• Mobile support (Supports Google Cardboard)

• Multiplayer (with websockets)

• Renders on server, streamed to clients

• Portals to link to scenes

• Uses WebGL

• Loads .xml scene descriptions

• Imports .obj models

• Audio support

• WebRTC voice chat

• Uses OpenTok for server multiplexing

• Server creates separate channel for each scene

• Script your worlds using JavaScript

• Supports jQuery

• Simulate physics with Cannon.js
http://cannonjs.org

• Renders with Three.js
http://threejs.org

• Interoperable with JanusVR (http://janusvr.com/)

• Declarative VR markup, similar to

 – A-frame by Mozilla

 – Glam by Tony Parisi

 – JanusVR by James McCrae

 – Metaroom by Tee Jia Hen

The goal is to converge

The Easy way

• Download the editor/server app

http://docs.scenevr.com/download.html

The hard way

• Install using npm

7. ReactJS

• “A JavaScript library for building user interfaces”

• The “V” in “MVC”, - independant of your technology stack

• Simplifies creating your interface dynamically in the browser, pre-rendered on the server, or powering a native mobile application

• Implements a one-way reactive data flow

• We have adopted this
for the new Meerkats website

8. ES2015 and Babel

• Formerly known as ES6

• ECMA TC39 will be making constant additions to ECMAScript

• It's no big deal

• Use Babel to adopt new features without fear

• We have adopted this
for the new Meerkats website

9. Webpack

• Simple* build process specifically for web projects

• I rejected this last year, but it hasn't gone away

• We have adopted this
for the new Meerkats website

* once you understand it :/

10. TypeScript

• Adds enforceable data types to JavaScript

• Reduce errors, improve understandability

• Enables Intellisense

• Supports ES201x

• Works great with ReactJS

• We'll get there eventually

11. CouchDB

• Cluster Of Unreliable Commodity Hardware (DB)

• Extremely failure resistant

• "If you get a response, your data is written
and safe"

• Clean shut down = pull the plug

• Replicates between peers

• Push or pull from any other CouchDB server

12. PouchDB

• The JavaScript database that syncs!

• "PouchDB was created to help web developers build applications that work as well offline as they do online."

• Replicate with CouchDB

• Create a new instance of PouchDB, sync with remote CouchDB - continuous replication

• Manage with Resources > IndexedDB - or Chrome plugin

• Can put HTML into local storage!

• See also Couchbase Lite for mobile devices
